objective: Test whether an object is a conductor or an insulator using a simple bulb circuit.
components: Test object (rubber, paper clip, coin, etc.)
steps: Connect one wire from the battery positive terminal to the bulb.
Connect another wire from the bulb to one end of the test object.
Connect the other end of the test object back to the battery negative terminal.
Observe whether the bulb glows.
If bulb glows, the object is a conductor. If not, it is an insulator.

component_working.Battery: Provides electrical energy for the circuit.
component_working.Bulb: Glows when current flows through it.
component_working.Test Object: Completes the circuit if it conducts electricity.

expected_output: Bulb glows for conductors like metals and stays off for insulators like plastic.
troubleshooting: If bulb does not glow, check all connections firmly.
Try testing with a known conductor like a paper clip.
safety_notes: Do not test objects connected to mains electricity.

objective: Learn to connect a basic 2-pin LED on a breadboard with correct polarity.
steps: Identify LED legs: longer leg is positive (anode), shorter leg is negative (cathode).
Insert LED legs into two different rows of the breadboard.
Connect LED anode row to battery positive rail.
Connect LED cathode row to battery negative rail.
Observe the LED glowing.

component_working.LED: Glows only when connected with correct polarity.
component_working.Breadboard: Provides internal row connections for circuit building.

expected_output: LED glows steadily when polarity is correct.
common_mistakes: Placing LED legs in same breadboard row
troubleshooting: If LED does not glow, flip the LED direction.
Ensure LED legs are placed in different rows.

objective: Understand how DC motor direction changes with polarity reversal.
steps: Connect one motor terminal to battery positive.
Connect the other motor terminal to battery negative.
Observe the motor spinning in one direction.
Reverse the battery connections.
Observe the motor spinning in the opposite direction.

component_working.DC Motor: Converts electrical energy into motion. Direction depends on polarity.
component_working.Battery: Provides power to run the motor.

expected_output: Motor spins forward, then reverses direction when polarity is swapped.
common_mistakes: Weak battery causing motor not to spin
troubleshooting: Check battery charge if motor does not spin.
Ensure wires are firmly attached to motor terminals.
safety_notes: Do not short the battery terminals.

experiment_name: RGB LED with Buzzer Breadboard Circuit
objective: Build a circuit combining an RGB LED and buzzer on a breadboard.
steps: Insert RGB LED pins into breadboard rows.
Insert buzzer pins into separate rows.
Connect LED common pin to ground rail.
Connect one color pin to battery positive through jumper.
Connect buzzer positive to battery positive rail.
Connect buzzer negative to ground rail.
Observe LED glowing and buzzer sounding.

component_working.RGB LED: Contains red, green, blue LEDs inside one package.

expected_output: RGB LED lights up and buzzer produces sound.
troubleshooting: Test LED colors one at a time.
Flip buzzer terminals if no sound.
safety_notes: Do not exceed buzzer voltage rating.

objective: Control a windmill motor and LED using switches on a breadboard.
steps: Insert motor terminals into breadboard.
Insert LED into breadboard rows.
Connect motor circuit through first switch.
Connect LED circuit through second switch.
Connect battery positive to switches input.
Connect outputs to motor and LED.
Toggle switches to control motor and LED independently.
expected_output: Switch controls motor and LED separately.
troubleshooting: Check switch connections if nothing works.
Flip LED if it does not glow.
safety_notes: Turn off power before changing wiring.

objective: Explore different motor types and observe basic working with polarity.
steps: Connect motor to battery terminals.
Observe spinning motion.
Reverse polarity and observe reversed direction.
Discuss applications of motors in daily life.

component_working.Motor: Provides rotary motion used in fans, toys, machines.

expected_output: Motor spins when powered and reverses when polarity changes.
common_mistakes: Motor not spinning due to weak battery
troubleshooting: Replace battery if motor does not spin.
safety_notes: Do not overload motors with high voltage.

objective: Control the brightness of an LED using a potentiometer as a dimmer.
steps: Insert potentiometer into breadboard.
Connect outer pins to positive and ground rails.
Connect middle pin to LED anode through resistor.
Connect LED cathode to ground.
Rotate knob to change brightness.

component_working.Potentiometer: Variable resistor that controls voltage output.

expected_output: LED brightness increases or decreases smoothly when knob is rotated.
troubleshooting: Ensure middle pin is connected to LED circuit.
safety_notes: Always use resistor to protect LED.

experiment_name: LDR Light Sensor with LED and Buzzer
objective: Build a light-sensitive alarm circuit using an LDR, LED and buzzer.
steps: Insert LDR into breadboard.
Create a voltage divider with LDR and resistor.
Connect LED to output node.
Connect buzzer to same node for alarm indication.
Cover LDR to simulate darkness.
Observe LED glowing and buzzer sounding.

component_working.LDR: Changes resistance based on light level.

expected_output: In darkness, LED glows and buzzer sounds; in light, both reduce activity.
common_mistakes: Incorrect resistor values causing no change
troubleshooting: Swap divider resistor values to adjust sensitivity.
safety_notes: Ensure correct polarity for LED and buzzer.
